page.title: 11S.W. GUILDFORD:LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The original Anglo-Saxon settlement of Gyldeforda was probably located around what is now Quarry St. Little evidence of the Anglo-Saxon settlement exists but the subsequently constructed Norman keep and castle remain to this day. In the Middle Ages the town was well known for its woollen textiles: its most famous product was "Guildford Blue" a fine woollen cloth dyed with locally produced woad. The R.Wey was used for transporting wool, textiles and agricultural goods. Guildford developed as an important route centre because of its position in the Wey gap. It was on the medieval Pilgrim's Way and later became an overnight stopping place for coaches travelling between London and Portsmouth. The Angel Inn on the High St. was one such place.{CONTINUED
